metadata.case_name: Matru alias Girish Chandra v. State

facts.text: Appellant Matru alias Girish Chandra, along with Mohar Singh and Saheb Singh, committed to Court of Sessions for trial under ss. 302/34 IPC for murder of Smt. Omwati (wife of Ram Chandra PW1) and their 3-year-old son Sua Lal, and under s. 382 IPC for theft from the house.
Offences alleged committed between 10 and 11 a.m. on May 29, 1964 in Shamsabad township. Appellant and deceased were next door neighbours in Mohalla Chaukhanda.

Ram Chandra left house at about 9 a.m. for shop 3 furlongs away, leaving wife Omwati and sons Ramji (6 years) and Sua Lal (3 years). Omwati sent elder son Ramji to shop with food around 10 a.m. Servant sent vegetables, later informed Ram Chandra of wife in pool of blood.
Ram Chandra found wife dead in courtyard near well, 3-year-old son dead in room nearby. Box opened, contents pilfered. Gold/silver ornaments missing which wife wore that morning.
FIR lodged at 12.40 p.m. at PS Shamsabad stating Rs. 200 cash and three ornaments including ring taken. No suspect named initially.
Appellant Matru, next door neighbour, came to Ram Chandra's house before FIR lodged and stayed till report made to police.
Investigating officer found blood at death scenes, collected blood-stained earth.

Next morning (May 30), Chhotey Lal PW2 informed Ram Chandra he saw Matru and two unknown persons entering Ram Chandra's house at 10-10.30 a.m. on May 29. Nathu Lal PW10 informed saw Matru and two others coming out at about 11 a.m.
facts.source: PW2 Chhotey Lal, PW10 Nathu Lal

facts.text: Six months prior, strained relations between Omwati and appellant's wife. Omwati suspected frequent visitors to appellant's house. Quarrel: appellant's wife threw stone/brick hitting Omwati on head. Ram Chandra did not take seriously initially.
Appellant remained in house till inquest over, then disappeared.
SI searched appellant's house May 30 at 9 a.m., not found, no incriminating articles.
Appellant apprehended June 1, 1964. Spectacle case containing spectacles and gold ring recovered from folds of dhoti.
Mohar Singh's complicity known on appellant's interrogation. Arrested Sept 13, 1964, recovered shawl sold to Darbarilal PW17.
Saheb Singh arrested on suspicion.

Sessions Judge convicted appellant under 302/34 IPC (life) and 382 IPC (4 years RI), sentences concurrent. Acquitted Mohar Singh of 302/34 and 382, convicted under 411 IPC (2 years RI). Acquitted Saheb Singh.
High Court upheld appellant's conviction, motive from strained relations, reliable PW2 and PW10, fair investigation, ring identified as deceased's, absconding. Acquitted Mohar Singh.
FIR described missing: gold chain 3 tolas Rs375, pair gold jhumki+kundal 1.5 tolas Rs150, gold ring longitudinal 0.5 tola Rs75, Rs200 cash. No mention of spectacle case/spectacles.
Recovery memo Ex.Ka-1: spectacle case black, spectacles brown frame white glasses, gold ring longitudinal green enamel red/blue design, somewhat bent.
Identification test held Oct 23, 1964 by Magistrate PW21, delayed due to procuring similar articles.
Ex.Ka-4 letter by deceased to father mentioning injury from brick by appellant's wife, challenged as inadmissible.
No weapon recovered, no blood stains on appellant's clothes noticed though with PW1 till FIR.

legal_issues.text: Whether circumstantial evidence establishes appellant's guilt beyond reasonable doubt
Admissibility of Ex.Ka-4 letter under s.32 Evidence Act
Applicability of s.34 IPC after acquittal of co-accused
Reliability of recovery and identification of stolen articles
Value of motive, eyewitness accounts of PW2 and PW10, and absconding

petitioner_arguments.text: Circumstantial evidence does not establish complicity; not conclusive and consistent only with guilt
Identification of recovered articles of little value as commonly available, no distinguishing marks
Ex.Ka-4 inadmissible as not relating to cause of death or circumstances under s.32 Evidence Act
S.34 IPC inapplicable after acquittal of co-accused Mohar Singh and Saheb Singh
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Prabhu Babaji Navle v. State of Bombay

respondent_arguments.text: Motive from strained relations, reliable PW2 and PW10, fair investigation, ring identified as deceased's, absconding connect appellant beyond doubt

court_reasoning.text: Went into evidence due to exceptional features: circumstantial case, co-accused acquitted, neighbour stayed till FIR, admissibility/value of Ex.Ka-4 and identification challenged
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.136 allows scrutiny in special circumstances to prevent injustice

court_reasoning.text: Eyewitness PW2 and PW10 believable for seeing appellant with two others enter/leave house around 10-11 a.m., but time approximate; unlikely to commit murder/theft in broad daylight seen by known barber PW2 without noticing
court_reasoning.key_observation: No potli mentioned, no abnormal behaviour noticed by PW10

court_reasoning.text: Recovery evidence unreliable: anonymous approver not produced, PW5 collected unknown witnesses quickly, no prior knowledge of Nathu PW10, testimonies inconsistent, no details from PW16
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot hold beyond doubt articles recovered from appellant

court_reasoning.text: Identification test unsatisfactory: delayed, articles shown to contractor, dissimilar mixed articles (old vs new cases), records missing
Motive weak: altercation not taken seriously by PW1, Ex.Ka-4 prima facie inadmissible, not strong enough for double murder
Absconding after FIR not necessarily guilty mind; innocent may panic. No weapon recovered, no blood on clothes despite presence till FIR
court_reasoning.key_observation: Chain of circumstances incomplete, admits other hypotheses

court_reasoning.text: S.34 not directly addressed but co-accused acquittal noted as exceptional feature

holdings.text: Circumstantial evidence falls short of excluding reasonable doubt; chain not complete for only conclusion of guilt
Recovery and identification not proved reliably
Ex.Ka-4 prima facie inadmissible under s.32 Evidence Act

precedents_cited.case_name: Prabhu Babaji Navle v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: S.34 IPC inapplicable after co-accused acquittal
Circumstantial evidence must be fully established, consistent only with guilt hypothesis

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences charged: murder with common intention, theft after murder preparation, handling stolen property

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Supplementary list hit by s.162; s.107 proceedings post-occurrence irrelevant for motive

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Special leave appeal; discretionary power to scrutinise evidence

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed, appellant's conviction and sentences under s.302/34 and s.382 IPC set aside, acquitted of all charges.

key_quotes.text: "the cumulative effect of the circumstantial evidence in this case falls far short of the test required for sustaining conviction."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on insufficiency of evidence leading to acquittal

key_quotes.text: "Suspicion however strong cannot take the place of proof."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects motive and eyewitnesses as insufficient for conviction

key_quotes.text: "Mere absconding by itself does not necessarily lead to a firm conclusion of guilty mind."
key_quotes.speaker: court
